response.answer_text: With nearly all disciplines in our society nowadays, I think there is hardly ever an instance where a particular field is rigidly isolated from other fields. Such as with writing, skills with grammar, spelling, and information literacy are utilized across the board, though in some industries those skills are specialized or altered to suit the industry’s needs (e.g. a biologist will write a paper, a journalist will write an article, and those to works will look vaguely similar because the content is vastly different). Biochemistry is applicable to the following fields: Higher education—a degree in biochemistry can be a doorway to greater education opportunities. Medicine—biochemistry is foundational knowledge for higher concepts in medicine, especially if one is pursuing a future in the medical field. Research—biochemical knowledge is essential to most fields of research, such as cell biology, molecular biology, genetics, material sciences, regenerative sciences, neuroscience, psychology, kinesiology, etc. The degree to which biochemistry is used in each respective field of research depends on what is being researched, though even a background knowledge can be useful. Engineering—chemical, petroleum, biomedical, biochemical, and material engineering all the potential to utilize biochemistry to some degree, and the knowledge from biochemistry can serve as a pathway for greater creations and advances. Manufacturing—technicians may be required to perform complex industrial manufacturing work using processes founded on basic biochemical formulas and principals. How to you make a compound, separate solutions, and optimize the use of chemicals? Pharmacy—biochemistry is huge here! How a drug interacts with the body is explained by the principles of biochemistry, so foundations in biochemistry are essential to research and work with pharmacology. Education—biochemistry is taught. It’s foundations begin in chemistry and physics classes in high school and advance to organic and advanced biochemistry and biomimetics in college and post-grad. Art—Sometimes art relies on biochemistry. Art history is in part made more scientific when the organic components of paintings and other works and analyzed to determine age, content, and land of origin. Business—the management, sale, and marketing of medical, pharmacological, and industrial products derived from biochemical procedures becomes a whole lot easier if one can talk the talk with others more specialized in the sciences behind such products. Journalism/writing—biochemical knowledge foundations make it possible to become a better writer within the sciences.

We study biochemistry because it is the best way to understand how life works in a fundamental way. Physics and chemistry shape the way reactions and processes work in nature, biochemistry takes the knowledge from chemistry to study the fundamental processes that make up biology. Both biochemistry and molecular biology are extremely important fields when it comes to basic research (knowledge for the sake of knowledge) and applied research. The body of biochemical knowledge we’ve gathered in the last fifty years has allowed a huge revolution in the medical, agroalimentary and even energy fields. Advances such as recombinant DNA technology, which allows for example the production of cheap insulin for people suffering from diabetes, are results of years of research in the biochemical basis of life, and this research has provided the means to alter living organisms to industrially create target molecules. Health sciences also get improved by knowledge in the field of biochemistry, cancer, HIV or other diseases will only be cured or treated once they are understood in a biochemical way. The last reason I would add, as a biochemistry student, is that we also study it because it is interesting to know how things work, and one of the most interesting things to research is how life works. This and also because it is so damn cool.

Original question: What are the scopes of biochemistry? This is going to be a fairly superficial answer. But here goes something: Biochemistry is the chemistry of living things. So understanding the chemical processes of life. That can encompass, or contribute to, a vast amount of different subjects, and it wouldn’t make sense to try to list all here. Generally, almost all of biology is biochemistry and biophysics, so physics and chemistry (which, when you break it down is also just very complex physics simplified) in living things. But much of it is so complex that we have subjects such as “biology” or “psychology” to tackle these, since they do not necessarily concern themselves with the chemical and physical details. So another way to say it, albeit not very detailed either: Biochemistry concerns itself with the parts of biology, that is not biophysics, and tries to understand the sub-microscopic details, not “just” the macroscopic features (e.g. behavior). Though in real life (studies and research), the two are not necessarily that separate. Biochemists learn about biophysics as well.

We study it, because whether you believe in creationism or evolution, there is a huge HUGE gap between "The Sun started shining" and "I tripped the other day an bruised my knee." (which I did). The HOW got left out and that's what we study everything for, the details of how. Whether it's how things (like me) fall down, not up, or how I now have a big greenish - yellow spot on my knee, inquiring minds want to know HOW. And, so far, the best way we have found that answers those questions consistently is science. In the case of my knee, how and why the color change occurred in just the way it did.In the science of biochemistry, we begin to see how the blood under the skin of my knee changes color (and now itches), rather than just sitting here and saying "wow, that's ugly and now it itches, too. Boo Hoo." I, for one, am not satisfied with that kind of answer.
